title: Translating ProjectCatalyst
description: イノベーション・ハブ（ProjectCatalyst）自体が彼らのローカル言語でリーチできなければ、人々は多言語リソースを構築することはできません。

f6_assessments.q0: Translation of the weekly townhalls is an important problem. The proposers are already active in translation and this proposal is to fund paying them and additional translators a modest sum per week. It would be nice to include information on which languages will be targeted for the translations. An eastern town hall has also recently started, are they going to offers services for this as well?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have already been delivering this, so it is highly likely they will be able to continue. It would be nice to see a little more information on how they will recruit the new translators, and choose the languages, as this is a key part of the plan.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposed plan is relatively simple and thus easy to audit. The live translation of townhall meetings can be monitored along with the number of languages this is provided in. Perhaps the funding agreement could be linked to the number of active translators and funds released based on this. It would be good to see some metrics around the impact this is having rather than just monitoring the provision of the translation service. How many people are listening in each language to the town halls live or on a recorded basis? This could be used to manage which languages are provided on an ongoing basis.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, this will likely help the global audience of Town Hall meeting to have better understanding during the meeting. This is align with the challenge to have multilingual resources.
f6_assessments.q1: The team consists of veteran live-translator. And they already have successful live-translation during Town Hall meeting. Project planning & budgeting is visible & reasonable. The problem is how to attract competent live-translator for other languages and stay doing live-translation every Town Hall meeting.
f6_assessments.q2: KPI is quite clear. For sure, we can track and audit the live-translator during each Town Hall meeting. But the community needs to be able to track also how the live-translator really get the equipment + training needed.

f6_assessments.q0:
Great idea andproposal. It is well written with a defined schedule, clear problem and solution and of high impact to the community of non-english speakers, as it is aimed in this campaing. If proper implemented, method can be scalable to other meetings or materials, with trained team.
In regards to suggestion, I'd consider to broaden the scope a little bit and also translate th materials (slides) used in the presentations and the annoucements in the channels (like telegram, twitter, etc). Id also consider a criteria for selecting which languages should be tranlated. it would be good to add automatic captions for meetings where you cant find a translator for a specific langauge (of course, the quality of this auto generated caption should be assessed beforehand). Also, it would be nice to have a communication plan on how to reach non english speakers community who dont even know about the townhall. An extra question is how to monetize this idea to keep it running even when it doent get the fund, after being implemented (how to make it self sustainable?). Other thing to consider is how trained trannslators could support on training new members of the translator team? If this is possible, costs could be avoided on new trainings after some point.
f6_assessments.q1:
two people already committed who already do this are enough to start off and know the challenges in this project. Team expansion will be needed as project evolves. 

Plan is sensible and costs breakdown are clear
f6_assessments.q2:
the metrics and milestones are clear in the roadmap and make sense (thoug not clear on how they get to these proposed targets, it would be nice to have the assumptions mentioned).
I dont see the challenges and risks listed here but Id include challenges related to making it self sustainable/funded, reaching new audiences, ensuring quality in very language, guarantee there'll always be the proposed number of translators to do the live translating and avoid trained translator evasion.

f6_assessments.q0: The impact of this idea could be huge if the co-proposers thought about more ways of making the knowledge reach the non-English speakers besides only translating the TownHall Meeting. Considering that most non-English speakers don't even know about Cardano existence, how would they get interested in participate of ProjectCatalyst?
f6_assessments.q1: The co-proposers seem to be able to make the project happen. The part they aren't able to do (training translators) they have a specialized school to cover. The budget is clear, the resources needed (like how many translators and how much money each phase would spend) and the project are step to step explained. Despite that, I don't think this idea is a good way to solve the problem.
f6_assessments.q2: The sugested metric (number of non-English speakers joining the Cardano Community) can be a usefull way to audit the project success. The questions behind this metric could be: how many non-English speakers people have arrived in Catalyst per month after the beginning of translations? How many people of these started to contribute with Catalyst in their own language?

f6_assessments.q0: Live translations of the townhalls for non-english speakers would be an important step to make the governance process more accessible and transparent for them
f6_assessments.q1: While the plan is doable and is sufficiently detailed. While the proposers seem involved with cardano community and are transparent about their professional experience, the project website is a bit disorganized and not done yet.
f6_assessments.q2: Some of the KPIs are a bit loosely defined, but apart from those, most are really measurable.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is very accurate when it comes to meeting the challenge's objectives. As stated in the description, in fact, only a small portion of the population speaks English in a more "natural" way, that is, as a mother tongue or even a second language (I myself am Brazilian, and I speak English quite easily because I studied when small, but I know I'm part of a privileged minority). A problem I found here was that the proposal is too broad, it promises to do very big things, but we don't know how things will happen in a particular way. For example: what content would be translated, exactly? The authors mention that town halls, forums and proposals should be translated. But during proposal development, translation is focused on town halls. So it would be beneficial if the authors confirmed that this would be the first content for translation and then gave a sense of how, little by little, other content in the Cardano ecosystem could be translated, because promising to translate everything without setting a goal that is easier to visualize is complicated. .. We are told which languages ​​they intend to address, which is a positive point. But because there are several, it would be important to know, for example, which would be addressed first. It was a little vague how the community would have access to the translated content; I believe that every proposal must establish a solid point between what is done and who is intended to benefit from the idea. For these reasons, I believe the impact of the proposal is high, but it needs detailing.
f6_assessments.q1: We are provided with little information about the authors. We know that they are translators, and that they have a website, which was attached, on which they intend to develop tools to facilitate the work of future translators. Tools such as: dashboard and direct communication channels between people hired. However, we do not have a deep background about their work. It would be very positive to attach some townhall or forums that they translated, and even introduce us to who the other people involved are, as we are told that there are already translators who were working for free. I think it was necessary to leave this network of contacts a little more exposed in the proposal. The site they have attached is very good, you can see that they know what they do: what we lack is more demonstration.
f6_assessments.q2: Regarding the applicability of the project, I believe it is the most detailed part of the proposal. We are told what is intended to be done in certain blocks of time (3 months, 6 months and more future steps), and also how the financial amount would be used. About detailing, we have a pretty safe notion, however, that could be further broken down. Let me explain: on the part of the money destined for the website, for example, they ask for 500 dollars to keep a job for 6 months. Okay, but what job is this? I thought they needed to explain more about how they were going to build the site, which despite being well underway, still needs to be filled with more content. Of course, a UI/UX designer must be a contract, because having access to the translations in a simple and direct way is as important as the fact that the translations exist. The self-worth (in my opinion) requested for town hall translations is justified by the fact that future translators are well trained. It would even be positive if some website or content were attached that explained more how the Frankfurt School operates in this blockchain universe, because most of us evaluators do not know its work and would add value to the proposal. It is also positive how the authors establish success metrics, so the community could better track the progress of the project. Thus, although we already have a good sense of information about how things will happen in practice, some issues are still confused, lacking clarification, but in general I found the auditability satisfactory.

f6_assessments.q0: They show what they are capable of and have a very detailed plan of what they are going to do as well as a large set of goals. Since they are both already translators they obviously then have some experience in this area. One thing they haven't mentioned though is about how they will get new translators.
f6_assessments.q1: It is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully because the proposer/s have a simple plan to get more translators and to get paid for it. They are also currently translating the Townhall presentations.
f6_assessments.q2: It is easy to audit the progress because they have a concise plan to get paid for translating and to get more translators. Some of the goals may be hard to achieve such as getting a 70% rise in users on Cardano, but otherwise their success would be easy to audit.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal effectively addresses the challenge and is a necessary component to add to project catalyst. As a regular attendee of the townhalls, I instantly see the value of this proposal. If Cardano is to truly be global, it requires the global reach, which cannot be done with English alone. In addition, the proposal as presented here is comprehensive and it is clear that the proposers thought through what is required very thoroughly. Great work.
f6_assessments.q1: Given the experience and plan presented it is extremely likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully. The benefit of this proposal compared to others is that they are already doing the work. Having attended many THs with the live translation, the effect of this work is already being seen. To this end, there is no doubt that it would continue to be implemented successfully. Given that this issue will likely persist going forward, the proposers have shown that they are already thinking ahead and have a plan for how to ramp up their efforts. One way the proposal could be strengthened would be by entertaining a discussion on sustainability. Is there a way to get more regular funding for these efforts? While the $ may be good now, submitting a new proposal for each fund may not be appropriate. Providing some thoughts about setting up dedicated funding for the continuance of this work would also be valuable.
f6_assessments.q2:
The reason why I am not giving this criteria a 5 is because I think more information could be provided on how the training (from the Frankfurt school) will improve the translations. While it may help the translators better understand blockchain, I am not sure I see the leap to better translations. Are there particular courses that support live translation skill development? Why did you choose the blockchain masterclass over building the skills for live translation? Also, what if someone becomes a translator but doesn't take the class? Would they still be included? What would the process be for removing a translator? These issues will help ensure that voters can be confident the proposal is successful. 

The budget seems more than fair for what is requested and may not be enough given the time commitment for the translators.

solution: ProjectCatalystやTownHall-Meetingでは、誰もが参加できるように提案を翻訳する必要があります。
experience: JonnyとAlainは、毎週開催されるTownHall Meetingを定期的にライブ翻訳しています。また、ジョニーはカルダノフォーラムの翻訳者としても活躍しています。
